Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Evaluating PVI for Fluid Responsiveness in Modified Prone Position

Participants.evidence: included 50 patients aged 20-80 years with ASA physical status I-III, excluding those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cardiovascular disease, pulmonary disease, obesity, or renal disorders

Intervention.evidence: Participants received a 4 mL/kg crystalloid load in both supine and modified prone positions

Objective.evidence: aimed to evaluate the ability of pleth variability index (PVI) to predict fluid responsiveness in the modified prone position during cervical spine surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: Fluid responsiveness was defined as a ≥15% increase in stroke volume (SV) measured by FloTrac/Vigileo™

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 50 patients, 43 were analyzed after excluding those with surgery cancellation or vasoactive drug use

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04002193)

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by institutional resources
